meanings.def: to pull somebody/something along with effort and difficulty
examples: drag somebody/something The sack is too heavy to lift—you’ll have to drag it.
drag somebody/something + adv./prep. I dragged the chair over to the window.
They dragged her from her bed.
He quickly dragged a comb through his hair.
drag somebody/something + adj. She managed to drag him clear of the wreckage.
Pull the chair nearer the table.
They use oxen to pull their carts.
The sack is too heavy to lift—you’ll have to drag it.
I drew my chair closer to the fire.
a horse-drawn carriage
Fishermen were hauling in their nets.
Our car was towed away by the police.
She tried to escape but he tugged her back.
Police dragged protesters away from the embassy entrance.
Dogs drag the sledges for hundreds of miles across the snow.

meanings.def: to take hold of something and pull it
examples: Desperately, Jinny dragged at his arm.

meanings.def: to move yourself slowly and with effort
examples: drag yourself + adv./prep. I managed to drag myself out of bed.
+ adv./prep. She always drags behind when we walk anywhere.
He dragged himself back home.
She dragged herself up the stairs by the banister.

meanings.def: to persuade somebody to come or go somewhere they do not really want to come or go to
examples: I'm sorry to drag you all this way in the heat.
The party was so good I couldn't drag myself away.
He came in, dragging his three children behind him.
My parents used to drag me to piano lessons when I was a kid.
It's time you dragged yourself away from that computer!
I know you like hanging out in the mall, but I don't know why you have to drag me with you.
She dragged her eyes away from his.
Time dragged terribly.
The meeting really dragged.

meanings.def: to move, or make something move, partly touching the ground
examples: This dress is too long—it drags on the ground when I walk.
drag something He was dragging his coat in the mud.

meanings.def: to search the bottom of a river, lake, etc. with nets or hooks
examples: They dragged the canal for the murder weapon.

meanings.def: to move some text, an icon, etc. across the screen of a computer using the mouse
examples: Click on the file and drag it across.

meanings.def: to be deliberately slow in doing something or in making a decision
to criticize or say bad things about somebody in public, in a way that is unfair
examples: The paper has dragged his name through the mud.
They feel their agency has been dragged through the mud by the press.
Football's good name is being dragged through the dirt.

meanings.def: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all
examples: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

meanings.def: to improve your situation yourself, without help from other people

idioms.def: to be deliberately slow in doing something or in making a decision

idioms.idiom: drag somebody through the mud/dirt | drag somebody's name through the mud/dirt
idioms.def: to criticize or say bad things about somebody in public, in a way that is unfair
examples: The paper has dragged his name through the mud.
They feel their agency has been dragged through the mud by the press.
Football's good name is being dragged through the dirt.

idioms.def: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all
examples: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

idioms.idiom: pull/drag yourself up by your (own) bootstraps
idioms.def: to improve your situation yourself, without help from other people

meanings.def: a boring person or thing; something that is annoying
examples: He's such a drag.
Walking's a drag—let's drive there.
Having to work late every day is a drag.
It’s a real drag having to go all the way to London for the interview.

meanings.def: a person or thing that makes progress difficult
examples: He came to be seen as a drag on his own party's prospects.

meanings.def: an act of breathing in smoke from a cigarette, etc.
examples: She took a long drag on her cigarette.

meanings.def: clothes that are usually worn by the opposite sex (usually women’s clothes worn by a man as part of an entertainment)
examples: in drag He performed in drag.

meanings.def: the force of the air that acts against the movement of an aircraft or other vehicle
